loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is married with three children, all of whom go to school. She lives in her own house, where she has electricity and running water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Rose has operated a shoe and handbag selling business for the past four years. She sells from home to her neighbors and passers-by. 

With this loan of KES 30,000 she wants to purchase sacks of shoes and handbags for resale. She decided to join Yehu for this financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of shoes and handbags for resale.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is a widowed woman with four children, three adults and one still in school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. 

Rehema operates a cafe business preparing various foods. She cites seasonality as her major challenge.

With the 50,000 KES, she wants to purchase stocks of goods, maize flour, wheat flour and rice for the business. She joined Yehu to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stocks of goods, maize flour, wheat flour, rice for the business.

loans.name: Philice

texts.en:
Philice is a business woman who is very hardworking. She is married with three children, all of whom go to school. She lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

Philice has operated a charcoal selling business for the past 2 years. Her potential clients are neighbours and passersby. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future. 

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase 10 sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase 10 sacks of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Mbula

texts.en:
Mbula is a married woman who has been blessed with three school-going children. She lives in her own house, which has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mbula operates a charcoal selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and villagers. Her greatest monthly challenge is the high cost of transportation.

She is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES to purchase charcoal to resell. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal to resell

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is a married woman with two children who are in school. She lives at a rental house that has no piped water but has electricity. She cites school fees as her highest monthly expense.

Eunice has operated a beauty salon business for the past twelve years. Her potential customers are women. She dreams of earning more income and building her own house in the future. 

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase a blowdryer for her business. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase a blowdryer for her business

loans.name: Tunu

texts.en:
Tunu is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family, thanks to her hard work.

She is asking for a loan to purchase wheat flour, rice, and biscuits for resale. She is grateful for the new support she has received.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, rice, and biscuits for resale.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married mother of two schoolgoing children. She lives in her own house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She makes soft drinks using fruits and juice flavors and sells them to her neighbors and passersby. She cites seasonality as her major challenge.

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase juice flavors and fruits for the business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase juice flavors and fruits for the business.

loans.name: Majaliwa

texts.en:
Majaliwa appreciates her previous Kiva loan, which improved her living standards. 

She is requesting a loan of 30,000 Kenya shillings (KES) to purchase bales of clothes for resale. 

Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
This is Rehema. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She thanks Kiva lenders for their financial support. She has been in this business for years now, and it keeps on growing.
 
She would like to apply for a loan of 30,000 Kenya shillings to buy more stock of food ingredients, such as wheat flour, maize flour, rice and sugar. 

She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

loans.use: to buy more stock of food ingredients, such as wheat flour, maize flour, rice and sugar.

loans.name: Annastacia

texts.en:
Annastacia is married with two school-going children. They live in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Annastacia has operated a vegetable stall business for the past six years. She sells from home to her neighbors. She dreams of establishing a mini green grocer in the future.

With the KShs 50,000, she wants to purchase bales of green vegetables for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase bales of green vegetables for resale

loans.name: Mwaka

texts.en:
Mwaka is married with three children, two in school and one who is too young to go to school yet. They live in a rental house that has electricity but not running water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mwaka has operated juice-making business for the past three years. She sells from home to her neighbors. 

With this loan of KES 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of passionfruit, carrots and sugar for her business. She decided to join Yehu to gain this financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of passionfruit,carrots and sugar for her business

loans.name: Annastacia

texts.en:
Annastacia is a married woman with one child who goes to school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For over four years, she has operated a fruit and vegetable stall business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of establishing a grocery store in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000, she wants to purchase stock of green vegetables, fruits,tomatoes, potatoes and onions. She decided to join Yehu to access a loan to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of green vegetables, fruits,tomatoes, potatoes and onions for her food stall business.

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en:
Mwanamisi is a single woman with no children. She owns a house that has no electricity but has piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

For the past year, she has operated a clothing and charcoal selling business, selling clothes for both men and women. She cites stiff competition as her major challenge in the business. 

Mwanamisi is requesting for Kshs 20,000 to purchase bales of clothes and charcoal for resale. She joined Yehu to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes and charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Langoni

texts.en:
Langoni is asking for a loan because she believes that through it she will improve her business. She is requesting a loan of 40,000 KES to purchase more bundles of firewood and sacks of charcoal for her business.

Her previous loan enabled her to save money from her firewood and charcoal selling business. She feels that she was able to make a good investment with her previous loan, which to date has allowed her to maintain her level of profits to help her family cover their personal expenses

loans.use: to purchase more bundles of firewood and sacks of charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Mejumaa

texts.en:
Mejumaa is a business woman who is very hardworking. She is married with three children, two in school and one underage. She lives in her own house that doesn't have electricity nor piped water. 

Mejumaa has operated a charcoal selling business for the past five months. Her potential clients are neighbors and passersby.

With the Kshs 20,000, she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Mgeni

texts.en:
Mgeni is a business woman who is very hardworking.  Mgeni is married with four children who go to school.  She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. 

Mgeni has operated a charcoal selling business for the past 2 years.  Her potential clients are neighbours and passersby.  She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.  With the KES 40,000 she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale and pay school fees for her children.  She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale and pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Tumaini

texts.en:
Tumaini is a married woman with eight children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For over ten years, she has operated a fruits and vegetables stall business, selling from the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of establishing a grocery store in the future.

With the KES 40,000, she wants to purchase stock of green vegetables, fruits, tomatoes, potatoes and onions. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of green vegetables, fruits, tomatoes, potatoes and onions.

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en: Mwanajuma appreciates Kiva lenders' support for her previous loan that improved her tailoring business and enabled her to increase her income. She used the increased income to improve her living standards. She is requesting a loan of KES50,000 to pay school fees for her children. She joined Yehu to receive financial support.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice appreciates her previous loan, which enabled her to earn the profits she used to add more stock to her vegetable store business. Besides the vegetable store, Alice operates a tailoring business.

She is requesting a loan of KES 50,000 to purchase more textile materials for her business. She appreciates Kiva and Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase more textile materials for her business.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a married woman, and she has four school-going children. She lives in a rental house, which has electricity, but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past six years, she has operated a food stall, preparing various foods to sell to her neighbours and passersby, such as rice, flat bread, and beans. She mentioned seasonality as her major challenge.

With the KES 40,000 loan, she wants to purchase charcoal and food ingredients for her business, including wheat flour, rice, beans and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans, to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase food ingredients (such as wheat flour, beans and cooking oil) and charcoal for her business

loans.name: Patronala

texts.en:
This is Patronala. Her previous loans were a big help in her business. She was able to purchase more bales of clothes to sell. Besides the clothes-selling business, she also prepares fried fish and sells them to her customers.

She would like to apply for a loan of KES 50,000. She will use this loan to buy more fish, for her business. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

loans.use: to buy more fish to cook and sell

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is a very hardworking and enterprising woman. She says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family, thanks to her hard work.

She is asking for a loan, which she will use to buy more bales of second-hand clothes for her business. She is grateful for the new support she has received.

loans.use: to buy more bales of second-hand clothes for her business.

loans.name: Salama

texts.en:
Salama appreciates her previous loan that helped improve her living standards. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income.
She thanks Kiva lenders for supporting her financially.
She would like to apply for a loan of ksh. 50,000 to buy food ingredients such as onions, cooking oil, tomatoes, rice for her business. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to buy ingredients such as onions, cooking oil, tomatoes, and rice for her business.

loans.name: Mejumaa

texts.en:
Mejumaa is a married woman with three children who go to school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mejumaa operates a food making business, making comestibles like beans and chapati (flat bread) for sale to passersby and neighbours.

With the KES 40,000 she wants to purchase food items, such as wheat flour, cooking oil, sugar and beans. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income and establish a restaurant in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase food items such as wheat flour, cooking oil, sugar and beans.

loans.name: Freshia

texts.en:
Freshia is married, and has two school-aged children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food for the family and school fees.

For the past three years, she has operated a poultry selling business. She sells to her neighbors and passersby. Her major challenges are high cost of transportation to her place of operation.

With the Ksh 50,000, she wants to purchase chicks and chicken feeds. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and improve her living standards.

loans.use: to purchase chicks and chicken feeds.

loans.name: Mwanaiki

texts.en:
Mwanaiki is a married woman with three children. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mwanaiki operates a food preparing business making various foods such as fried potatoes and chapati (flat bread).

With the KES 30,000, she wants to purchase food ingredients such as potatoes, cooking oil, sugar, wheat flour and charcoal for her business. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income and establish a restaurant in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase food ingredients such as potatoes, cooking oil, sugar, wheat flour and charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Bintimohamed

texts.en:
Bintimohamed is a married woman with two children who go to school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past five years, Bintimohamed has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the 20,000 KES Bintimohamed wants to purchase sugar, maize flour, rice, beans, and cooking oil for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, maize flour, rice, beans, and cooking oil for resale

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family, thanks to her hard work.  Besides the clothes business, Monica also operates a food stall.

She is asking for a loan to buy ingredients, such as wheat flour, milk, eggs and maize flour for resale. She is grateful for the new support she has received.

loans.use: to buy ingredients such as wheat flour, milk, eggs and maize flour for resale

loans.name: Riziki

texts.en:
Riziki is married and has two children, one in school the other is still underage. She lives at her own house that has electricity, but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is household consumables.

For over five years she has operated a tailoring business, making garments for both men and women, along with curtains. She cites seasonality as her major challenge. 

With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase cloth and sewing materials for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth and sewing materials for her business.

loans.name: Mariamu

texts.en:
Mariamu is a married woman with four children, one in school and three adults. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food. 

For the past 20 years, Mariamu has operated a food stall business, preparing various foods such as rice, flat bread, beans and selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned seasonality as her major challenge. 

With the 30,000 KES, Mariamu wants to purchase wheat flour, maize flour, beans, and cooking oil for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, maize flour, beans, and cooking oil for her business.

loans.name: Mauwa

texts.en: Mauwa appreciates for her previous Kiva loan that improved her living standards and enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She is requesting for a loan of 50,000 KES to purchase bales of women’s wrap cloths for resale.  She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase bales of women's wrap cloths for resale.

loans.name: Bintiali

texts.en:
Bintiali is married and has eight children, three in school and the rest are adults. She lives at her own house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are household consumables and school fees.

For over six years she has operated a food stall business, selling items such as groundnuts, bread and milk.

Bintiali is requesting for a loan of ksh.30,000 to pay school fees for her children. Her dream is to see her children become better people in the society.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Nuru

texts.en:
Nuru is a single woman with one child, who goes to school. She owns a house that has no electricity but has piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For over a year, Nuru has operated a fruit and vegetable stall, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of establishing a grocery store in the future.

With the 20,000 KES, she wants to purchase stock of green vegetables, fruits, tomatoes, potatoes and onions for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of green vegetables, fruits, tomatoes, potatoes and onions

loans.name: Mebakari

texts.en:
Mebakari is a married mother of five children who are in school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food for the family.

Mebakari has operated a cashew nut selling business at the market for the past thirteen years, selling to passersby and neighbours. She cited seasonality as her major challenge in the business.

With the 30,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES) she wants to purchase sacks of cashew nuts for resale. She joined Yehu to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of cashew nuts for resale.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
This is Mariam. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She was able to purchase sacks of charcoal. 

Besides the charcoal-selling business, Mariam sells paraffin and coconuts. She would like to apply for a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more kerosene and coconuts for her business. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and the educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

loans.use: to buy more kerosene and coconuts for her business.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is married and has five children, four of whom attend school. She is a hardworking and enterprising woman who lives in the coastal region of Kenya. For the past 12 years, she has operated a chemist shop business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. Price fluctuation is her major challenge. 

Fatuma requested a loan from Yehu for 50,000 KES, which she will use to purchase antibiotics to sell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food.

loans.use: to purchase antibiotics to sell.

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en: Mwanakombo appreciates for her previous Kiva loan that improved her living standards and enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She is now requesting a new loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to purchase maize flour, sacks of sugar, and salt for resale. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, sacks of sugar, and salt for resale.

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en:
Saumu is a hardworking and enterprising woman. She is a married mother of three children who are in school. She owns a house that has neither  electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Saumu bakes cakes and prepares samosa using sugar, cooking oil, and wheat flour and sells to neighbors and passersby. She cites seasonality as her major challenge.

With the KES 28,960 she wants to purchase wheat flour and sugar and pay school fees for her children. She joined Yehu to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour and sugar and to pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Violet's Group

texts.en:
Violet is a member of this group in Chwele District.  She is pictured here in a group of 6 One Acre Fund group leader farmers.  The group leaders represent a total of 65 individual One Acre Fund farmers who are not pictured here.  Violet has been selected to act as the Kiva group representative and is standing on the right with her hand raised.  She and the other farmers represented in this group are each receiving ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of sorghum or millet.  Each farmer is receiving an average input loan of 5,349 shillings for maize, millet and sorghum cultivation.
							
Violet is 41 years old and has been a farmer for 17 years.  Violet works as a farmer to provide for her 4 children.  The community and other farmers know Violet as hardworking.  Other than farming, she is also involved in her community's activities such as the women's group.  Violet described her harvest last year as excellent, but hopes she can have an even better one with the support of One Acre Fund and the other farmers in her group.
							
The 2013 Long Rains season won’t be Violet’s first season with One Acre Fund.  She first joined One Acre Fund in 2010 and has continued working with One Acre Fund in order to earn enough to feed family.  As an active member in her community, Violet also chose to be a group leader and Kiva representative because she wants to help more farmers.  Violet plans on using future profits from the harvest to send children to school.  Her life has improved by working with One Acre Fund because she has more profits from harvest.							

Violet and her group need a loan to cover the initial costs of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer through One Acre Fund.  One Acre Fund will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the farmers through the profits from the farmers’ harvests.  One Acre Fund pre-purchases the seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings to the farmers.  Throughout the planting and harvesting season, One Acre Fund also provides training and support to the farmers as they make payments back to One Acre Fund.  With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.

loans.use: get access to hybrid seed and fertilizer for harvesting maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Leah's Group

texts.en:
Leah is a member of this group in Matete District. She is pictured here in a group of nine One Acre Fund group leader farmers. The group leaders represent a total of 89 individual One Acre Fund farmers who are not pictured here. Leah has been selected to act as the Kiva group representative and is standing on the right, with her hand raised. The field officer is also included in the photo and is standing on the left of the photo. Leah and the other farmers represented in this group are each receiving ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of sorghum or millet. Each farmer is receiving an average input loan of KES 5,349 (shillings) for maize, millet, and sorghum cultivation.
							
Leah is married and has eight children.  She is 48 years old and is known as friendly, hard-working, reliable, trustworthy, and an experienced farmer.  She is active in her community, in groups such as the women's group, prayer group, and burial committee. Leah has been a farmer for 20 years. She described her harvest as good last year, but she believes she can have an even better one this year, by continuing to work with One Acre Fund.
  							
Leah first enrolled with One Acre Fund in 2011 and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2014 Long Rains season. She joined One Acre Fund in order to get the best seed prices and get new farming methods. She also volunteered to be a group leader and Kiva representative because she likes being a leader and, as an active community member, she wants to help more farmers. 

Leah plans to use the money that she earns from her next harvest to send her children to school, repair the home, and save money for the future. She notes that working with One Acre Fund has led to many benefits for One Acre Fund farmers. Leah’s own life was improved because she has more farm training, was able to save money, and feed the family. 
 							
Leah and her group need a loan to cover the initial costs of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer through One Acre Fund.  One Acre Fund will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the farmers, through the profits from the farmers’ harvests. 

One Acre Fund pre-purchases the seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings to the farmers. Throughout the planting and harvesting season, One Acre Fund also provides training and support to the farmers, as they make payments back to One Acre Fund. With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits, and improved lives.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Joseph's Group

texts.en:
Joseph  is a member of this group in Matete District.  He is pictured here in a group of 8 One Acre Fund group leader farmers.  The group leaders represent a total of 86 individual One Acre Fund farmers who are not pictured here.  Joseph  has been selected to act as the Kiva group representative and is standing on the right with his hand raised.  He and the other farmers represented in this group are each receiving ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of sorghum or millet.  Each farmer is receiving an average input loan of 5,349 shillings for maize, millet and sorghum cultivation.

He is active in his community in groups such as the men's group, savings group and prayer group.  Joseph  has been a farmer for 33 years.  Joseph  described his harvest as good last year, but believes he can have an even better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund.
  							
Joseph  first enrolled with One Acre Fund in 2010 and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2014 Long Rains season.  Joseph  joined One Acre Fund in order to send his children to school.  He also volunteered to be a group leader and Kiva representative because he likes being a leader, and an active community member.  Joseph  plans to use the money that he earns from his next harvest to send his children to school, repair the home, save for the future and buy a cow.  He notes that working with One Acre Fund has lead to many benefits for One Acre Fund farmers.  Joseph ’s own life was improved because he has more farm training.
  							
Joseph  and his group need a loan to cover the initial costs of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer through One Acre Fund.  One Acre Fund will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the farmers through the profits from the farmers’ harvests.  One Acre Fund pre-purchases the seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings to the farmers.  Throughout the planting and harvesting season, One Acre Fund also provides training and support to the farmers as they make payments back to One Acre Fund.  With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.
							
The field officer is also included in the photo and is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Ayub's Group

texts.en:
Ayub is a member of this group in Matete District.  He is pictured here in a group of 4 One Acre Fund group leader farmers.  The group leaders represent a total of 37 individual One Acre Fund farmers who are not pictured here.  Ayub has been selected to act as the Kiva group representative and is standing on the right with his hand raised.  He and the other farmers represented in this group are each receiving ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of sorghum or millet.  Each farmer is receiving an average input loan of 5,349 shillings for maize, millet and sorghum cultivation.	
						
Ayub is married and has 8 children.  He is 39 years old and is known as hardworking and trustworthy.  He is active in his community in groups such as the men's group and savings group.  Ayub has been a farmer for 10 years.  Ayub described his harvest as excellent last year, but believes he can have an even better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund.  
							
Ayub first enrolled with One Acre Fund in 2012 and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2014 Long Rains season.  Ayub joined One Acre Fund in order to get new farming methods and send his children to school.  He also volunteered to be a group leader and Kiva representative because he likes being a leader and is an active community member who wants to spread the story about One Acre Fund farmers.  Ayub plans to use the money that he earns from his next harvest to save for the future.  He notes that working with One Acre Fund has lead to many benefits for One Acre Fund farmers.  Ayub’s own life was improved because he has more farm training, was able to save money and feed the family.  					

Ayub and his group need a loan to cover the initial costs of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer through One Acre Fund.  One Acre Fund will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the farmers through the profits from the farmers’ harvests.  One Acre Fund pre-purchases the seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings to the farmers.  Throughout the planting and harvesting season, One Acre Fund also provides training and support to the farmers as they make payments back to One Acre Fund.  With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.							

The field officer is also included in the photo and is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Anjela

texts.en: Anjela is a mother of three school-aged children; they are 15, 13 and 12 years old. She lives with her children, husband and mother-in-law in Tegh village. Anjela and her husband have been involved in agriculture for seven years. They own 20 cows and 10 calves. Anjela uses the milk for cheese production and her husband sells it at local markets. The income from agriculture is vital to the family, so Anjela would like to increase the size of her livestock. She is requesting a loan of USD1,500 to purchase five more calves. She hopes for lenders' support and goodwill.

loans.use: to pay for five calves.

loans.name: Johnston's Group

texts.en:
Johnston is a member of this group, located in the Matete District. He is pictured here in a group of nine One Acre Fund group leader farmers. The group leaders represents a total of 93 individual One Acre Fund farmers who are not pictured here. Each farmer is receiving an average input loan of 5,349 shillings for maize, millet and sorghum cultivation. Johnston has been selected to act as the Kiva group representative and is standing on the right with his hand raised. He and the other farmers represented in this group are each receiving ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of sorghum or millet.

Johnston is married and has 4 children.  He is 38 years old and is known as friendly, hardworking, trustworthy, and an experienced farmer. He is active in his community and participates in groups such as the prayer group. Johnston has been a farmer for 9 years. Johnston described his harvest as good last year, but he believes that he can have an even better harvest this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund. 
 							
Johnston first enrolled with One Acre Fund in 2013 and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2014 Long Rains season.  Johnston joined One Acre Fund in order to learn new farming methods and get fertilizer and hybrid seeds. He also volunteered to be a group leader and Kiva representative because he is an active community member who wants to spread the story about One Acre Fund farmers. Johnston plans to use the money that he earns from his next harvest to save for the future. He notes that working with One Acre Fund leads to many benefits for One Acre Fund farmers. Johnston’s own life was improved because he was able to save money and feed his family.
  							
Johnston and his group need a loan to cover the initial costs of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer through One Acre Fund. One Acre Fund will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the farmers through the profits from the farmers’ harvests. One Acre Fund pre-purchases the seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings to the farmers. Throughout the planting and harvesting season, One Acre Fund also provides training and support to the farmers as they make payments back to One Acre Fund.  With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits, and improved lives.

loans.use: to gain access to cost efficient hybrid seeds for maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Rose's Group

texts.en:
Rose is a member of this group, located in the Matete District. She is pictured here, in a group of nine One Acre Fund group leader farmers. The group leaders represent a total of 91 individual One Acre Fund farmers who are not pictured here. Each farmer is receiving an average input loan of 5,349 shillings for maize, millet and sorghum cultivation. 
Rose has been selected to act as the Kiva group representative and is standing on the right with her hand raised. She and the other farmers represented in this group are each receiving ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of sorghum or millet.  

Rose is 36 years old and has been a farmer for 15 years. Rose works as a farmer to provide for her 4 children. The community and her fellow farmers know Rose as hardworking and reliable. Other than farming, she is also involved in her community in groups such as the savings group.  Rose described her harvest last year as good, but hopes that she can have an even better harvest with the support of One Acre Fund and the other farmers in her group.
							
Rose joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2014 season as a group leader. Rose joined One Acre Fund so that she could learn new farming methods and get fertilizer and hybrid seeds.  Because she is an active community member, she wants to help more farmers.  Rose has gotten more involved with One Acre Fund as a group leader and Kiva representative. Working with One Acre Fund has improved Rose's life because she is able to feed her family. In the future, Rose hopes that her profits from 2014 can be used to send her children to school and save for the future. 

One Acre Fund focuses on working with smallholder farmers across Kenya. The organization pre-purchases seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings onto the farmers. Rose and her group will use the Kiva loan to cover the initial cost of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer package from One Acre Fund. One Acre Fund continues providing training and support throughout the planting and harvesting season to ensure a good harvest and repayment. With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.

loans.name: Margaret's Group

texts.en:
This group consists of three group leader farmers, located in the Matete District. Margaret has volunteered to be the Kiva group representative and is on the right of the photo with her hand raised. Farming inputs will be delivered to her and the 29 other individual farmers represented in this group. The credit consists of the necessary materials to plant ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of millet or sorghum.  The individual farmers are not pictured here but will be receiving an average loan of 5,349 shillings.

Margaret is married and has six children. She is 50 years old and is known as friendly. She is active in her community, in groups such as the women's group. Margaret has been a farmer for 35 years. Margaret described her harvest as excellent last year, but believes she can have an even better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund. 

Margaret joined One Acre Fund in 2011, and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2014 season as a group leader.  Margaret joined One Acre Fund so that she could earn enough to feed her family. Because she is an active member of the community, Margaret has become more involved with One Acre Fund as a group leader and Kiva representative. In the future, Margaret hopes that her profits from 2014 can be used to buy a cow. 

One Acre Fund focuses on working with smallholder farmers across Kenya. The organization pre-purchases seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings onto the farmers. Rose and her group will use the Kiva loan to cover the initial cost of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer package from One Acre Fund. One Acre Fund continues providing training and support throughout the planting and harvesting season to ensure a good harvest and repayment. With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.		

The field officer is also included in the photo and is standing on the left of the photo.

The group leaders in this group represent a total of 28 individual farmers (not pictured) who are each asking for an average loan of 5,349 shillings to purchase a One Acre Fund package for ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of sorghum or millet.  As the Kiva group representative, Patrick  is pictured on the right of the group with his hand raised.	
						
Patrick is a reliable member of the community.  He is married with 13 children.  Patrick is 67 years old and has been working as a farmer for the last 30 years to support his family.  In addition to this, Patrick is very active in his community and is involved in the men's group and savings group.  He described his harvest last year as good.  He hopes to continue working with One Acre Fund and to continue with the success he is having with the One Acre Fund farm packages.							

Patrick joined One Acre Fund in 2012, and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2014 season as a group leader.  Patrick joined One Acre Fund so that he could get the best seed prices, get fertilizer, and hybrid seeds. Because he is an active community member, he wants to help more farmers and spread the story about One Acre Fund farmers.  Patrick has gotten more involved with One Acre Fund as a group leader and Kiva representative.  Working with One Acre Fund has improved Patrick's life.  Because he has more profits from harvest, he was able to save money and feed the family. In the future, Patrick  hopes that his profits from 2014 can be used to send his children to school and to buy a cow. 
 							
Patrick and his group need a loan to cover the initial costs of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer through One Acre Fund.  One Acre Fund will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the farmers through the profits from the farmers’ harvests. One Acre Fund pre-purchases the seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings to the farmers.  Throughout the planting and harvesting season, One Acre Fund also provides training and support to the farmers as they make payments back to One Acre Fund.  With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.							

The field officer is also included in the photo and is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: to support farmers in purchasing hybrid seeds and fertilizer to increase better harvests of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Vincent's Group

texts.en:
Vincent is a member of this group in Chwele District. He is pictured here in a group of seven One Acre Fund group leader farmers. The group leaders represent a total of 72 individual One Acre Fund farmers who are not pictured here. Vincent has been selected to act as the Kiva group representative and is standing on the right with his hand raised. The field officer is also included in the photo and is standing on the left.
							
Vincent and the other farmers represented in this group are each receiving hybrid seed and fertilizer for ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of sorghum or millet. Each farmer is receiving an average input loan of 5,349 shillings for maize, millet and sorghum cultivation.
							
Vincent is married and has five children. He is 42 years old and is known as friendly, hardworking, reliable, trustworthy and an experienced farmer. He is active in his community in groups, such as the men's group, savings group, prayer group and burial committee. Vincent has been a farmer for twenty years. He described his harvest as good last year, but believes he can have an even better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund.
  							
Vincent first enrolled with One Acre Fund in 2009 and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2014 Long Rains season. He joined One Acre Fund in order to get the best seed prices, get new farming methods, get fertilizer and hybrid seeds, earn enough to feed his family and send his children to school. He also volunteered to be a group leader and Kiva representative because he is an active community member who wants to help more farmers and spread the story about One Acre Fund farmers.  

Vincent plans to use the money that he earns from his next harvest to send his children to school and invest in a business. He notes that working with One Acre Fund has led to many benefits for One Acre Fund farmers. Vincent’s own life was improved because he has more profits from the harvests and has more farm group support.
				
Vincent and his group need a loan to cover the initial costs of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer through One Acre Fund. One Acre Fund will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the farmers through the profits from the farmers’ harvests.

One Acre Fund pre-purchases the seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings to the farmers. Throughout the planting and harvesting season, One Acre Fund also provides training and support to the farmers as they make payments back to One Acre Fund. 

With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet and sorghum.

loans.name: Repha's Group

texts.en:
This group consists of six group leader farmers in Matete District with Repha selected as the Kiva representative. Repha has volunteered to be the Kiva group representative and is on the right of the photo with her hand raised. Farming inputs will be delivered to her and 61 other individual farmers represented by this group. The credit consists of the necessary materials to plant ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of millet or sorghum. The individual farmers are not pictured here but will be receiving an average loan of 5,349 KES.
							
Repha is 40 years old and has been a farmer for 30 years. She works as a farmer to provide for her three children. The community and other farmers know Repha as hardworking and reliable. She is also involved in her community in groups such as the women's group. Repha described her harvest last year as good, but hopes she can have an even better one with the support of One Acre Fund and the other farmers in her group.
							
Repha joined One Acre Fund in 2013 and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2014 season as a group leader. She joined One Acre Fund so that she could learn about new farming methods. Because she is an active community member, Repha has gotten more involved with One Acre Fund as a group leader and Kiva representative. Working with One Acre Fund has improved Repha's life because she was able to feed her family. In the future, she hopes that her profits from 2014 can be used to send her children to school.  							

One Acre Fund focuses on working with smallholder farmers across Kenya. The organization pre-purchases seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings onto the farmers. Repha and her group will use the Kiva loan to cover this initial cost of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer package from One Acre Fund. One Acre Fund continues providing training and support throughout the planting and harvesting season to ensure a good harvest and repayment. With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits, and improved lives.

loans.use: to buy cost-efficient maize, millet, and sorghum seeds.

Celestine joined One Acre Fund in 2011, and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2014 season as a group leader.  Celestine joined One Acre Fund so that she could get the best seed prices and send her children to school.  Because she likes being a leader and an active community member, she wants to help more farmers by spreading the story about One Acre Fund farmers. Celestine has gotten more involved with One Acre Fund as a group leader and Kiva representative.  Working with One Acre Fund has improved Celestine's life because she has more profits from harvest and is now able to feed her family.  In the future, Celestine hopes that her profits from 2014 can be used to send her children to school and repair her home.

Celestine and her group need a loan to cover the initial costs of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer through One Acre Fund.  One Acre Fund will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the farmers through the profits from the farmers’ harvests.  One Acre Fund pre-purchases the seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings to the farmers.  Throughout the planting and harvesting season, One Acre Fund also provides training and support to the farmers as they make payments back to One Acre Fund.  With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.							

The field officer is also included in the photo and is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To gain access to cost efficient hybrid seeds for maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Joseph's Group

texts.en:
Joseph  is a member of this group in Matete District.  He is pictured here in a group of three One Acre Fund group leader farmers.  The group leaders represent a total of 29 individual One Acre Fund farmers who are not pictured here.  Joseph  has been selected to act as the Kiva group representative and is standing on the right with his hand raised.  He and the other farmers represented in this group are each receiving ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of sorghum or millet.  Each farmer is receiving an average input loan of 5,349 shillings for maize, millet and sorghum cultivation.
							
Joseph is married and has six children.  He is 48 years old and is known as friendly, hard-working and trustworthy.  He is active in his community in groups such as the men's group and savings group.  Joseph has been a farmer for 25 years.  Joseph described his harvest as good last year, but believes he can have an even better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund.
  							
Joseph first enrolled with One Acre Fund in 2012 and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2014 Long Rains season.  Joseph joined One Acre Fund in order to get the best seed prices, learn new farming methods, and buy fertilizer and hybrid seeds.  He also volunteered to be a group leader and Kiva representative because he likes being a leader and is also an active community member.  Joseph plans to use the money that he earns from his next harvest to send his children to school.  He notes that working with One Acre Fund has led to many benefits for One Acre Fund farmers.  Joseph’s own life was improved because he has more profit from harvest and was able to feed the family.
  							
Joseph and his group need a loan to cover the initial costs of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer through One Acre Fund.  One Acre Fund will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the farmers through the profits from the farmers’ harvests. One Acre Fund pre-purchases the seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings to the farmers.  Throughout the planting and harvesting season, One Acre Fund also provides training and support to the farmers as they make payments back to One Acre Fund.  With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.
							
The field officer is also included in the photo and is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Agnes' Group

texts.en:
Agnes’s group has 5 group leader farmers and is located in Kakamega North District.  The group leaders in this group represent a total of 50 individual farmers (not pictured) who are each asking for an average loan of 5,349 shillings to purchase a One Acre Fund package for ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of sorghum or millet.  As the Kiva group representative, Agnes is pictured on the right of the group with her hand raised.	
						
Agnes is married and has 6 children.  She is 51 years old and is known as friendly, hardworking, reliable, trustworthy and an experienced farmer.  She is active in her community in groups such as the women's group, savings group and prayer group.  Agnes has been a farmer for 25 years.  Agnes described her harvest as good last year, but believes she can have an even better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund.
  							
Agnes first enrolled with One Acre Fund in 2010 and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2014 Long Rains season.  Agnes joined One Acre Fund in order to get the best seed prices, get new farming methods, get fertilizer and hybrid seeds, earn enough to feed family and send her children to school.  She also volunteered to be a group leader and Kiva representative because she is an active community member who wants to help more farmers.  Agnes plans to use the money that she earns from her next harvest to send children to school, repair the home, buy a cow and invest in a business.  She notes that working with One Acre Fund has lead to many benefits for One Acre Fund farmers.  Agnes’s own life was improved because she has more profits from harvest, has more farm training and group support, was able to save money and feed the family.  							

Agnes and her group need a loan to cover the initial costs of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer through One Acre Fund.  One Acre Fund will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the farmers through the profits from the farmers’ harvests.  One Acre Fund pre-purchases the seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings to the farmers.  Throughout the planting and harvesting season, One Acre Fund also provides training and support to the farmers as they make payments back to One Acre Fund.  With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.							

The field officer is also included in the photo and is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To allow farmers the opportunity to buy cost efficient maize, millet, and sorghum seeds.

loans.name: Knight's Group

texts.en:
This group consists of six group leader farmers in the Chwele District with Knight selected as the Kiva representative.  Knight has volunteered to be the Kiva group representative and is on the right of the photo with her hand raised.  Farming inputs will be delivered to her and the 65 other individual farmers represented in this group.  The credit consists of the necessary materials to plant ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of millet or sorghum.  The individual farmers are not pictured here but will be receiving an average loan of 5,349 shillings.							

Knight is 27-years-old and has been a farmer for 10 years.  Knight works as a farmer to provide for her four children.  The community and other farmers know Knight as friendly and trustworthy.  Other than farming, she is also involved in her community in groups such as the women's group.  Knight described her harvest last year as excellent, but hopes she can have an even better one with the support of One Acre Fund and the other farmers in her group.

The 2014 Long Rains season won’t be Knight’s first season with One Acre Fund.  She first joined One Acre Fund in 2010 and has continued working with One Acre Fund in order to get the best seed prices and get new farming methods.  As an active member in her community, Knight also chose to be a group leader and Kiva representative.  Knight plans on using future profits from the harvest to send her children to school and buy a cow.  Her life has improved by working with One Acre Fund because she was able to save money and was able to feed the family.

One Acre Fund focuses on working with smallholder farmers across Kenya.  The organization pre-purchases seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings onto the farmers.  Knight and her group will use the Kiva loan to cover this initial cost of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer package from One Acre Fund.  One Acre Fund continues providing training and support throughout the planting and harvesting season to ensure a good harvest and repayment.  With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.	

The field officer is also included in the photo and is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To gain access to cost efficient hybrid seeds to plant maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: John's Group

texts.en:
John  is a member of this group in Busia District.  He is pictured here in a group of 7 One Acre Fund group leader farmers.  The group leaders represent a total of 66 individual One Acre Fund farmers who are not pictured here.  John  has been selected to act as the Kiva group representative and is standing on the right with his hand raised.  He and the other farmers represented in this group are each receiving ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of sorghum or millet.  Each farmer is receiving an average input loan of 5,349 shillings for maize, millet and sorghum cultivation.		
					
John  is married and has 8 children.  He is 64 years old and is known as friendly, hardworking, and an experienced farmer.  He is active in his community in groups such as the men's group and prayer group.  John  has been a farmer for 15 years.  John  described his harvest as excellent last year, but believes he can have an even better one this year by continuing to work with One Acre Fund.  		

John  first enrolled with One Acre Fund in 2013 and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2014 Long Rains season.  John  joined One Acre Fund in order to get the best seed prices, get new farming methods and earn enough to feed family.  He also volunteered to be a group leader and Kiva representative because he likes being a leader who wants to help more farmers and spread the story about One Acre Fund farmers.  John  plans to use the money that he earns from his next harvest to repair his home and save for the future.  He notes that working with One Acre Fund has lead to many benefits for One Acre Fund farmers.  John’s own life was improved because he has more profits from the harvest, has more farm training and was able to feed the family.  
							
John and his group need a loan to cover the initial costs of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer through One Acre Fund.  One Acre Fund will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the farmers through the profits from the farmers’ harvests.  One Acre Fund pre-purchases the seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings to the farmers.  Throughout the planting and harvesting season, One Acre Fund also provides training and support to the farmers as they make payments back to One Acre Fund.  With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.

The Field officer is also included and he is standing on the left side of the photo.

loans.use: To purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Annah's Group

texts.en:
Annah’s group has 6 group leader farmers and is located in Kakamega North District. The group leaders in this group represent a total of 59 individual farmers (not pictured) who are each asking for an average loan of 5,349 shillings to purchase a One Acre Fund package for ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of sorghum or millet. As the Kiva group representative, Annah is pictured on the right of the group with her hand raised.
		
Annah is a reliable member of the community. She is married with 4 children. Annah is 42 years old and has been working as a farmer for the last 25 years to support her family. In addition to this, Annah is very active in her community and is involved in the women's group. She described her harvest last year as excellent. She hopes to continue working with One Acre Fund and to continue with the success she is having with the One Acre Fund farm packages.							

The 2013 Long Rains season won’t be Annah’s first season with One Acre Fund. She first joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and has continued working with One Acre Fund in order to get fertilizer and hybrid seeds. As an active member in her community, Annah also chose to be a group leader and Kiva representative because she wants to help more farmers and spread the story about One Acre Fund farmers. Annah plans on using future profits from the harvest to send children to school and buy a cow. Her life has improved by working with One Acre Fund because she has more farm training and was able to feed the family.							

Annah and her group need a loan to cover the initial costs of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer through One Acre Fund. One Acre Fund will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the farmers through the profits from the farmers’ harvests. One Acre Fund pre-purchases the seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings to the farmers. Throughout the planting and harvesting season, One Acre Fund also provides training and support to the farmers as they make payments back to One Acre Fund. With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.							

The field officer is also included in the photo and is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To gain access to cost-efficient hybrid seeds for maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Prosperidad Y Responsabilidad Group

texts.es: El grupo “Prosperidad y Responsabilidad” conformado por 06 socios prósperos. Luz de 23 años de edad es soltera y no tiene hijos. Luz y su madre se dedican a la venta de productos naturales, inicio hace más de 03 meses en su negocio. Luz desea incrementar su cartera de clientes, es por ello que solicitó el crédito para la compra de productos como tónico y jalea real. El grupo “Prosperidad y Responsabilidad” agradece a los inversionistas Kiva por hacer posible este crédito. Luz es la tercera del lado derecho y viste chaleco plomo con blusa blanca.
texts.en: The Prosperity and Responsibility group is made up of six prosperous members. Luz, 23, is single and does not have children. Luz and her mother are dedicated to selling natural products. She started her business more than three months ago. Luz wishes to increase her list of customers. It is for this that she has requested the loan to buy products like tonic and royal jelly. The Prosperity and Responsibility group is thankful to the Kiva investors for making this loan possible. Luz is the third from the right side dressed in the grey vest and white blouse.

loans.use: for the purchase of products like tonic and royal jelly.

loans.name: Bibiana

texts.es:
Bibiana vive en la hermosa ciudad del Cusco y pertenece al banco comunal “Imasumac II” de la Asociación Arariwa. Ella tiene 63 años de edad,  es casada y tiene 7 hijos. Ella es una mujer trabajadora que saca adelante a su familia con el esfuerzo de su trabajo,  ella  se dedica a la venta de  verduras y frutas. En esta oportunidad requiere el préstamo para comprar frutas como por ejemplo plátanos, sandilla, papayas, peras y otras verduras como por ejemplo cebolla, tomate, papa y otras. 

Agradece el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas de acuerdo al cronograma de pagos.
texts.en:
Bibiana lives in the beautiful city of Cusco and is a member of the Communal Bank “Imasumac II”, which is part of Asociación Arariwa. She is 63 years old, married, and has seven children. She is a hardworking woman who is able to move her family forward as a result of the efforts of her work. Bibiana sells fruits and vegetables. She is taking this opportunity to request a loan in order to buy fruits such as bananas, watermelons, papayas, pears, as well as vegetables such as onions, tomatoes, potatoes, and other produce.

Bibiana is grateful for the loan and promises to complete her payments according to the schedule.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Hafiz

texts.en: Hafiz is from occupied territory of Azerbaijan Republic – Fuzuli city. Today he is living in Absheron region with his family, so they are Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs). The family consists of 3 people: Hafiz’s wife, who is a housewife, and his child, who is going to first class of school. Hafiz is 31 years old, and for 4 years he has been in the taxi driving business. Today he wants to repair his car’s motor. Therefore he needs a loan in the amount of 800 AZN (Azerbaijan new manat). Hafiz says thanks to the Kiva organization for aid.

loans.use: to repair his car’s motor

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy merchandise like, for example, underwear and polos.

loans.name: Nelli

texts.en:
Nelli is 24 years old, and she lives in Ijevan city, in Tavush region. Despite her young age, Nelli already has a rich credit history with Kiva and Nor Horizon. She has already paid off, in accordance with the repayment schedules, three Kiva loans.

Now, she needs one more loan (the fourth one), which she will use for her business development. She is an extremely brave and active girl. She was 18 years old when she established her beauty salon, and for some time she worked at both the salon and her food shop. She says that now her sister helps her in hairdressing activities. Nelli and her mother are seriously engaged in the food trading business. The products in her shop are very different and always fresh, so she is sure that she will never lack customers in her shop.

She asks a loan of 1,200,000 Armenian drams. She will use this amount to renew and to buy a new assortment of products for her shop.

loans.use: to renew and to buy a new assortment of products for her shop

loans.name: Felix

texts.es: Felix de 54 años de edad, habita al suroccidente de la ciudad, conoce muy bien las frutas tropicales, verduras tuberculos etc. cultivados en la región, pues tiene 24 años de dedicarse a ofrecer las más clasificadas para venderlas de contado y a crédito. Sus principales clientes, son vendedores que gritan en las calles: “Patillas, mangos, papayas, corozos ciruela vendo yo” ….. Todo esto con el fin de estimular la venta haciéndose  notar de las amas de casa, quienes al escucharlos salen a comprar en la misma puerta de su casa. La meta de Felix es ampliar la oferta de productos de la región y agregarle otras frutas  importadas, que tienen muy buena demanda en el mercado. Felix compra sus productos directamente a agricultores y mayoristas, pues ofrecen los mejores precios y  frutas frescas.  En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará  a por mayor y de contado ñame, yuca, tomate, corozo, ciruela, coco, aguacate, papaya y mango al por mayor, con esta compra ganará descuentos especiales, por su compra en volumen, haciendo de su credikiva una inversión exitosa
texts.en:
Felix, who is 54 years old, lives in the southwest of the city. He knows very well the tropical fruits, green vegetables, and tubers that are cultivated in the region. For 24 years he has dedicated himself to offering a variety of these products for cash or credit.
   
Felix's principal customers are vendors who cry out in the streets: “I sell watermelons, mangos, papayas, palm nuts, and plums.” All this is to stimulate sales, attracting the attention of housewives who upon hearing the call, come out to buy from their front doors.

His goal is to expand the regional products he offers and add other imported fruits that have very good market demand.  Feliz buys his products directly from farmers and wholesalers, then offers the best prices and freshest fruits.

At present, he is applying for a Kiva loan, his 1st financing through the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation, by means of which he will purchase for cash at wholesale yams, manioc, tomatoes, palm nuts, plums, coconuts, avocados, papayas, and mangos. By purchasing in volume he will earn special discounts, converting his Kiva loan into a successful investment.

loans.use: to buy at wholesale  for cash yams, manioc, tomatoes, palm nuts, plums, coconuts, avocados, papayas, and mangos to sell.

loans.name: Gioconda De Los Angeles

texts.es: Doña Gioconda es originaria de la ciudad de Managua, casada y madre de seis hijos, tres de ellos ya independientes. Es de oficio comerciante, se dedica a la venta de mercadería variada. Se siente agradecida con KIVA y MiCrédito ya que logro incrementar su inventario. Solicita el crédito para comprar: Plata y Acero. Estima que el crédito le será de mucha ayuda ya que obtendrá mayores ganancias, logrando así cubrir sus necesidades y gastos.
texts.en: Gioconda is a native of the city of Managua. She is married and mother to six children. Three of them are adults. She is a trader. She is dedicated to selling varied merchandise. She feels thankful to Kiva and MiCredito since she managed to increase her inventory. She is requesting the loan to buy silver and steel. She estimates that the loan will be great help since she will obtain better earnings allowing her to cover her needs and expenses.

loans.use: to buy silver and steel.

loans.name: Lusine

texts.en:
Lusine lives in Goris town, with her parents and brother. She studies at Goris State University, in the Economics Department. Lusine studies hard to become a good economist, and her parents work hard to provide the family's living.

As covering Lusine's education costs is very difficult for this family, Lusine has decided to ask a loan to pay for her university tuition. She will be very grateful if lenders support her with this loan and give her an opportunity to continue her studies.

loans.use: to pay for university tuition

loans.name: Mirna Emperatriz

texts.es:
Mirna es una mujer muy luchadora de 46 años de edad, con mucho esfuerzo ha logrado sacar adelante a sus hijos, a pesar de ser una madre viuda,  ha logrado mantener a sus  4 hijos y 2 hijas, jóvenes muy trabajadores que se dedican a la agricultura. Mirna solo estudio hasta sexto grado, debido a que en ese tiempo, las condiciones en que vivían sus padres no le permitían seguir estudiando, por lo que ella se tenía que incorporar a las actividades del hogar.  Hasta que un día decidió formar su propia familia,  por la que hoy en día lucha fuertemente.

Mirna se dedica a los oficios domésticos, junto a sus hijas que le ayudan en las actividades del hogar, así también apoya a sus hijos que trabajan fuertemente como agricultores, un trabajo que no es nada fácil, pero que hay que realizarlo por la necesidad de seguir adelante.

Mirna invertirá el crédito en la compra de un caballo, para utilizarlo para jalar leña y a la vez aprovechar la oportunidad, de poder comprarlo en la época en que están a un precio más accesible al que normalmente se mantienen en otro tiempo. 

Mirna sueña con poder comprar un caballo para facilitar la movilización de los productos agrícolas en la época de cosecha  y jalar leña en la época seca, ya que desde donde la traen está un poco lejos  y se le es difícil a sus hijos cargarla sobre la espalda  hasta su casa, con este animal de carga podrá ayudarle a sus hijos y podrá  servirles de apoyo en las labores agrícolas.
texts.en:
Mirna is a very hard-working woman who is 46 years old. With much effort, she has been able to bring her children out ahead despite being a widowed mother. She has been able to support her 4 sons and 2 daughters, very hard-working youths that make a living in agriculture. Mirna only studied to the sixth grade since in that time the conditions in which her parents lived did not permit her to continue studying. She had to join in with the housework until one day she decided to start her own family, for which she currently is strongly fighting.

Mirna makes a living in domestic work, along with her daughters who help her with the housework. She also supports her sons who work hard as farmers, a work that is not at all easy, but has to be done due to the necessity of carrying on.

Mirna will invest the loan in the purchase of a horse to use to haul firewood. She will also take advantage of the opportunity of being able to purchase at a time in which they are at a more accessible price than they are normally at other times.

Mirna dreams of being able to purchase a horse to facilitate the movement of agricultural products in harvest time and pull firewood in the dry season, since where it is brought from is a little far and is difficult for her sons to carry it home on their backs. This pack animal will be able to help her sons and support them in the agricultural labor.

loans.use: to purchase a horse.

loans.name: Gulbahor

texts.ru: Гулбахор 48-летняя замужняя женщина, проживает с мужем и детьми в селе района Шахритус. Сейчас она вместе с мужем готовится начать бизнес по купле и продаже крупнорогатого скота. По их словам данный прибыльный бизнес поможет им улучшить качество жизни семьи. Гулбахор и ее муж планируют покупать скот с близлежащего скотного рынка и откармливать в течение 30-35 дней. На сумму от кредита Гулбахор хочет закупить двух голов крупнорогатого скота. Благодаря кредиту у них будет работа и стабильный доход. Они с надеждой ждут поддержки.
texts.en: Gulbahor is a 48-year-old married woman who lives with her husband and children in a village in the Shahrituz region. She and her husband are preparing to start a business buying and selling cattle. In their words, this income-generating business will help them improve their family's quality of life. Gulbahor and her husband plan to purchase cattle at the nearby cattle market and to fatten them over 30 to 35 days. She intends to purchase two head of cattle with the loan amount. Thanks to the loan, they will have work and stable income. They hopefully wait for your support.

loans.use: to buy and sell two head of cattle

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah is widowed with three children, and all her children are in school. She doesn’t have any additional family members. She has a business selling chicken. She has been in this business for 2 years and has applied for a loan of 1,500,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more chicken for resale. She works in a shop and sells on a wholesale basis six days out of every week. Her major business challenge includes thieves and seasonality. She aspires to rear chicken herself and also to buy a plot so as to build chicken houses. She resides in the family house, and the family has no access to electricity. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more chicken to sell

loans.name: Alicia Martina

texts.es:
Alicia se dedica a la venta de útiles de escritorio en su domicilio. Ya son varios años que se dedica al negocio y le va muy bien. En esta oportunidad requiere el préstamo para comprar más útiles de escritorio como por ejemplo papel y cuardernos. 

Alicia se siente contenta por otro préstamo y se compromete a pagar las cuotas puntuales y con mucha responsabilidad. Agradece a todos los inversionistas por el préstamo y desea que sigan apoyando a los demás proyectos.
texts.en:
Alicia is dedicated to the sale of stationery from her home.She has been dedicated to this business for many years already and it is going very well. At this time, she needs a loan to buy more stationery like, for example, paper and notebooks.

Alicia feels happy for the other loan and promises to pay punctually and with much responsibility. She is thankful to all the investors for the loan and wishes they keep supporting other projects.

loans.use: to buy paper and notebooks.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
Victoria se dedica a la venta de verduras como por ejemplo cebollas, papas, tomates, apios, zanahorias, maíz y entre otros, ella pertenece al banco comunal "Cusco" desde hace varios años y en esta oportunidad requiere el préstamo para comprar más verduras como por ejemplo papas y cebollas.

Victoria  se siente contenta por el préstamo y se compromete a pagar las cuotas puntuales y con mucha responsabilidad. Agradece a todos los inversionistas por el préstamo y desea que sigan apoyando a los demás proyectos.
texts.en:
Victoria makes her living selling vegetables, like onions, potatoes, tomatoes, celery, carrots, corn and other items.  She has belonged to the communal bank called "Cusco" for several years.  At this time, she needs the loan to purchase more vegetables, like potatoes and onions. 

Victoria is happy about the loan and she promises to be responsible and punctual in repaying her loan.  She is grateful to all the investors for the loan, and she hopes that they keep helping with the other projects.

loans.use: to purchase more vegetables, like onions and potatoes.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 45-years-old.  She is married to Daniel and together they have five children, ages 26, 24, 22, 20 and 18. She has been in the farming business for the last 10 years and currently earns KES 30,000 per month.

This is Mary’s second loan with VisionFund Kenya and she intends to purchase farm inputs like seeds, fertilizer and animal feed for her cattle. 

She intends to improve the livelihood of her family from the anticipated profits.  Her hope and dream is to buy land for her family

loans.use: to buy farm supplies and goods and feed for her cattle

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en: Rehema appreciates her previous Kiva loan that improved her living standards and enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She is requesting a loan of KES 20,000 to purchase more cashew nuts for resale. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase more cashew nuts for resale

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha appreciates her previous Kiva loan that improved her living standards and enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income.

She is requesting for a loan of KES 40,000 to purchase more food ingredients for her business, such as wheat flour and cooking oil. 

She thanks Yehu Microfinance Trust for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase more food ingredients for her business, such as wheat flour and cooking oil.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more fish

loans.name: Heriqnaz

texts.en:
Heriqnaz is from Svarants village, Syuniq region. She lives with her husband and 7-year-old daughter and is involved in agriculture. She has been running her farm for 17 years and takes care of it with great love and pleasure. 

Heriqnaz keeps livestock (3 cows and 10 sheep) and also cultivates wheat. Agriculture is the only source of income for this family, so both Heriqnaz and her husband work hard to successfully run their farm.

Heriqnaz has now applied for this loan to enrich her livestock with 2 cows, with the hopes of having more income from agriculture. She hopes for lenders' trust and support.

loans.use: to pay for 2 calves

loans.name: Refik

texts.en: Refik is back again. He invested his previous loan, as planned, in buying olive trees. He has been doing very well in the olive-growing activity.

loans.use: to pay for the upfront rent of a store he has begun to operate, in his village

loans.name: Fiapai

texts.en: Fiapai is a 31-year-old single woman with two children. She has a small plantation and grows taro,yams, taamu, and bananas to earn a living. She has been doing this for three years. Fiapai has requested a loan to buy chemicals, a wheelbarrow, bush knives, weed-sprayer, and fertilizer. She has been a member of SBPD since 2011. With her profits, Fiapai hopes to extend her business and children's education as well.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, weedsprayer, bush knives, spades, and a wheelbarrow.

loans.name: Faatu

texts.en: Faatu is a 26 year old married woman who has no children. She has a small business, taro and taamu plantation.
